title: Mastering Lineplots_LB
text: can build single graph using following code:  can see arguments used function : data, dataframe variable, variable build lineplots time, x-axis variable
code: Lineplots_LB(data = data01,               variables = "Marker_1",               time = "Time") #> Loading required package: ggpubr #> Loading required package: dplyr #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union #> Loading required package: ggh4x #> Loading required package: grid #> Loading required package: gridExtra #>  #> Attaching package: 'gridExtra' #> The following object is masked from 'package:dplyr': #>  #>     combine #> Loading required package: svMisc #>  #> Attaching package: 'svMisc' #> The following object is masked from 'package:utils': #>  #>     ? #> Loading required package: officer #> Loading required package: rvg #> Loading required package: progress #> [[1]]

title: Mastering Lineplots_LB
text: can change lineplot graphics follows:
code: Lineplots_LB(data = data01, variables = "Marker_1", time = "Time") #> [[1]]

what: Single graph split by a group variable
title: Mastering Lineplots_LB
text: can also get separated curves specific grouping variable:
code: Lineplots_LB(data = data01, variables = "Marker_1", time = "Time", group = "Gender") #> [[1]]

title: Mastering Lineplots_LB
code: Lineplots_LB(data = data01, variables = c("Marker_1", "Marker_2"), time = "Time", group = "Gender") #> [[1]] #>  #> [[2]] #>  #> [[3]]

title: Mastering Lineplots_LB
text: can save list lineplots two different ways: can build grid save entire grid pdf file, can generate PPTX file every lineplot different slide.

what: Save a list of lineplots as a pdf grid file
title: Mastering Lineplots_LB
code: List_reg <- Lineplots_LB(data = data01, variables = c("Marker_1", "Marker_2"), time = "Time", group = "Gender")  LandS::Print_LB(plot_list = List_reg, path_print = "your/directory", ext = "pdf")

what: Save a list of lineplots as a PPTX file
title: Mastering Lineplots_LB
code: Lineplots_LB(data = data01, variables = c("Marker_1", "Marker_2"), time = "Time", group = "Gender",               PPTX = TRUE, grid = FALSE, pptx_width = 6, pptx_height = 4, target = "your/directory/new_presentation.pptx")

what: Customize the colour of the title
title: Mastering Lineplots_LB
code: library(dplyr) df_legend <- matrix(ncol = 2, nrow = 2) %>% as.data.frame() %>% `colnames<-`(c("Var", "Colour")) df_legend$Var <- c("Marker_1", "Marker_2") df_legend$Colour <- c("red", "orange")  colour_title <- function(i) df_legend$Colour[df_legend$Var == i]  Lineplots_LB(data = data01, variables = c("Marker_1", "Marker_2"), time = "Time", group = "Gender",               col_title = TRUE, colour_title = colour_title) #> [[1]] #>  #> [[2]] #>  #> [[3]]

what: Add overall and posthoc tests to the graphs
title: Mastering Lineplots_LB
code: # Let's make the grouping variable a factor data01$Time_fac <- factor(data01$Time, levels = c(1:5), ordered = TRUE)  # Run cont_var_test Tests <- LandS::cont_var_test_LB(data = data01, variables = c("Marker_1", "Marker_2"), group = "Time_fac",                                   paired = TRUE, p.adjust.method = "bonferroni") #> Loading required package: MASS #>  #> Attaching package: 'MASS' #> The following object is masked from 'package:dplyr': #>  #>     select #> Loading required package: PMCMRplus #> Loading required package: rlang #> Loading required package: gtsummary #> Friedman rank sum test used  Lineplots_LB(data = data01, time = "Time", variables = "Marker_1", Overall = TRUE, Test_results = Tests[[3]],               Posthoc = TRUE, posthoc_test_size = 2, threshold_posthoc = 1) #> [[1]]

title: This function creates a list of boxplot — Boxplot_LB
code: Boxplot_LB(   data,   variables,   group,   ID_lines = FALSE,   Posthoc = FALSE,   Point = F,   Median_line = F,   rm.outliers = F,   alpha_box = 0.1,   width_box = 0.2,   size_median_line = 0.8,   lwd_box = 0.1,   lwd_ID_line = 0.2,   alpha_ID_line = 0.3,   alpha_point = 0.3,   size_point = 0.3,   Test_results = NULL,   threshold_posthoc = 0.1,   posthoc_test_size = 3.88,   Overall = F,   notch = F,   notchwidth = 0.5,   axis_y_title = NULL,   axis_x_title = NULL,   size_axis_x = 6,   size_axis_y = 6,   ID = "ID",   legend_cod = NULL,   breaks_axis_x = levels(data[, group]),   labels_axis_x = levels(data[, group]),   grid = TRUE,   PPTX = FALSE,   pptx_width = 7.5,   pptx_height = 5.5,   extra = F,   extra_text = NULL,   palette_boxplot = c("salmon", "royalblue", "forestgreen", "gold"),   palette_title = "black",   size_title = 12,   target = paste0(path_out, "/Boxplot.pptx"),   ratio = 1,   telegram = "none" )

title: This function creates a list of boxplot — Boxplot_LB
text: data dataframe variables vector containing variables interest group factor variable splitting data ID_lines whether print lines paired observations Posthoc whether display Posthoc tests Point whether display observation points Median_line whether display line connecting medians rm.outliers whether remove outliers display alpha_box alpha parameter boxes width_box box's width size_median_line median linewidth lwd_box box linewidth lwd_ID_line linewidth paired observations alpha_ID_line alpha paired observations alpha_point alpha points size_point size points Test_results dataframe global posthoc tests, see cont_var_test_LB threshold_posthoc threshold displaying posthoc tests notch add notch boxplot notchwidth width notch axis_y_title axis y title axis_x_title axis x title size_axis_x axis y title dimension size_axis_y axis x title dimension ID ID variable

what: Function to build the lineplots — Lineplots_LB
title: Function to build the lineplots — Lineplots_LB
text: Function build lineplots

title: Function to build the lineplots — Lineplots_LB
code: Lineplots_LB(   data,   variables,   time,   breaks = unique(data[, time]),   label = unique(data[, time]),   group = 1,   col_lines = c("salmon", "royalblue"),   stat_line = "median",   smooth_line = FALSE,   span_line = 0.3,   lw_reg = 1,   alpha_line = 1,   ylim = c(0.2, 0.8),   ribbon = T,   alpha_ribbon = 0.05,   ID_lines = FALSE,   ID = "ID",   alpha_ID_line = 0.3,   lw_ID_line = 0.2,   Point = FALSE,   alpha_point = 0.3,   size_point = 0.3,   col_title = FALSE,   colour_title = NULL,   size_title = 7,   size_axis_x = 5,   size_axis_y = 6,   Overall = F,   Test_results = Test_results,   Posthoc = F,   threshold_posthoc = 0.1,   posthoc_test_size = 2,   grid = T,   ratio = 1,   PPTX = F,   pptx_width = 8.5,   pptx_height = 5.5,   target = paste0(path, "/file.pptx"),   label_title = paste0("Lineplots by ", group, "\n", format(Sys.Date(), "%d/%m/%Y")),   size_label_title = 2.5,   extra = F,   extra_text = NULL )

title: Function to build the lineplots — Lineplots_LB
text: data long-formatted dataframe variables Vector variables plot time Numeric variable plot x-axis breaks Numeric vector x-axis breaks. Default: unique(data[, time]) label Vector x-axis labels. Must length breaks. Default: unique(data[, time]) group Factor variable group lines col_lines Colours lines. Default: "salmon" & "royalblue" stat_line Statistic method line. "median" "mean" "" smooth_line Whether show smooth spline regression line. Defaul = FALSE span_line span smooth line. Defaul = 0.3 lw_reg Linewidth regression line alpha_line Alpha regression line ylim Limits y-axis plot. Default: c(0.20, 0.80) ribbon Whether show ribbons alpha_ribbon Alpha ribbons. Default: 0.05 ID_lines Whether show ID lines every patient ID ID variable. Default: "ID" alpha_ID_line Alpha ID lines. Default: 0.3 lw_ID_line Linewidth ID lines. Default: 0.2 Point Whether show points. Defaul = FALSE alpha_point Alpha points. Defaul = 0.3 size_point Size points. Defaul = 0.3 col_title Whether personalize colour title. Default = FALSE colour_title function personalize colour title. See vignette . size_title Size title. grid recommended 7, PPTX recommended 20 size_axis_x x-axis text size. grid recommended 5, PPTX recommended 14 size_axis_y y-axis text size. grid recommended 6, PPTX recommended 14 Overall Whether add overall test. Default = FALSE. See vignette . Test_results Dataframe overall posthoc tests. See vignette . Posthoc Whether add posthoc tests brackets.  Default = FALSE. See vignette . threshold_posthoc Threshold display posthoc brackets posthoc_test_size Size annotations posthoc p-values. Default = 2 grid Whether build grid pdf PPTX file. Default = TRUE ratio Graph ratio grid = TRUE PPTX Whether build PPTX grid pdf file. Default = FALSE. Must change grid = FALSE pptx_width Graph dimensions PPTX inches pptx_height Graph dimensions PPTX inches target Path save PPTX file label_title title list. Default sets "Lineplots grouping variable" current date size_label_title Size list's title. Default: 2.5 extra Whether add extra text function. Default = FALSE extra_text function add extra functions graphs. See vignette .

title: Function to build the lineplots — Lineplots_LB
text: grid = TRUE returns list ggplots. PPTX = TRUE grid = FALSE returns PPTX file target folder

what: Test for continuous variables splitted by categories — cont_var_test_LB
title: Test for continuous variables splitted by categories — cont_var_test_LB
text: powerful function ever created. can perform 4 major tests posthoc tests Friedman Kruskal-Wallis. dumb (option dumb = T) can also perform posthoc tests without correcting test multiplicity. Please try home/work consider asking statistician performing test.

title: Test for continuous variables splitted by categories — cont_var_test_LB
code: cont_var_test_LB(   data,   variables,   paired = FALSE,   group,   dumb = FALSE,   ID = "ID",   num_dec = 2,   p.adjust.method = c("bonferroni", "BH", "BY", "fdr", "none", "holm", "hochberg",     "hommel"),   excel = F,   excel_path = paste0(path_out, "/Results.xlsx"),   telegram = "none" )

title: Test for continuous variables splitted by categories — cont_var_test_LB
text: data dataframe variables vector containing variables interest paired FALSE/TRUE group factor variable splitting data dumb FALSE dumb? Hope ID ID variabl (Default = "ID") num_dec Decimal number mean SD (Default = 2) p.adjust.method correction method, character string. Can abbreviated. excel export fuction results multiple Excel sheets excel_path path want Excel telegram send telegram message
